author: Oliver Pickup
title: One-club men help grass roots rugby to flourish
text: Rugby union embraced professionalism only two decades ago so it is little wonder its amateur ethos still pervades the game. From the old mining towns of Wales to the Borders region of Scotland, for tens of thousands of people the local club remains their social hub, where lifelong friendships are formed and fostered. Important lessons are learnt through shared experiences, not least to be magnanimous in victory and sporting in defeat. For many, the rugby club is their life. Take Craig Taylor, a 60-year-old scrum-half nicknamed Fossil, who has been turning out for Whitehall Rugby Club in Bristol since the age of 15 and has played more than 1,200 games. He joined because he “found it a tight-knit community. You make friends wherever you go.” Thanks to the tireless and often thankless work of volunteers, grassroots rugby continues to flourish. One such man is Tudor Thomas, a head teacher who founded Cosby RFC, near Leicester. He served as president and later groundsman, marking out pitches well into his 70s. In 2007 he was granted lifelong member status at Leicester Tigers after a 45-year association with the club during which time he filled the roles of coach, player, secretary, president and chairman. Rugby needs selfless characters such as Thomas to thrive. And luckily it still has them.
